contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox scientist | name = Edwin Brant Frost II | birth_date = {{death date|1866|7|16}} | birth_place = [[Brattleboro]], [[Vermont]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1935|5|14|1866|7|16}} | death_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] | nationality = [[United States|American]] {{flagicon|USA}} | field = [[astronomy]] | alma_mater = [[Dartmouth College|Dartmouth]]}} '''Edwin Brant Frost II''' (July 16, 1866 – May 14, 1935) was an American [[astronomer]]. ==Biography== He was born in [[Brattleboro]], [[Vermont]]. His father, Carlton Pennington Frost,<ref name="struve"/> was dean of [[Dartmouth Medical School]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://dms.dartmouth.edu/about/history/history.shtml | title = Two Hundred Years of Medicine at Dartmouth | first = Barbara | last = Blough | coauthors = Dana Cook Grossman | publisher = Dartmouth Medical School | accessdate = 2008-06-25 }}</ref> Frost graduated from [[Dartmouth College|Dartmouth]] in 1886.<ref name="struve"> {{Cite document | first = Otto | last = Struve | author-link = Otto Struve | title = Biographical Memoir of Edwin Brant Frost|date=1937| publisher = [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America]]| url =http://books.nap.edu/html/biomems/efrost.pdf | postscript = <!--None--> }} </ref> He continued his education as a post-graduate student in chemistry and in 1887 became an instructor in physics while only 21 years old.<ref name="struve"/> In 1890 Frost went abroad to Europe and ended up researching [[stellar spectroscopy]] under [[Hermann Carl Vogel|Hermann Vogel]] in [[Astrophysical Institute Potsdam|Potsdam]]. He returned to [[Dartmouth College|Dartmouth]] in 1892 as an assistant professor of astronomy. He was fond of the outdoors and enjoyed [[golf]], [[swimming (sport)|swimming]], and [[ice skating]]. He also enjoyed [[music]] and [[literature]].<ref name="fox"/> In 1896 he married Mary E. Hazard. They had three children, Katharine, Frederick, and Benjamin.<ref name="struve"/> Frost joined the staff of [[Yerkes Observatory]] in 1898 and became its director in 1905 when [[George Ellery Hale|George Hale]] resigned. Frost kept the position until his retirement in 1932.<ref name="struve"/> He was the editor of the ''[[Astrophysical Journal]]'' from 1902 to 1932, known for his careful attention to details.<ref name="fox"/> In 1915 he lost the use of his right eye and in 1921, his left.<ref name="struve"/> Despite his blindness he continued working for eleven more years until his retirement in 1932. He died in 1935 in [[Chicago]] from [[peritonitis]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Edwin B. Frost, famous blind scientist, dies|date=May 15, 1935|publisher=[[Milwaukee Sentinel]]|url=http://wisconsinhistory.org/WLHBA/articleView.asp?pg=1&id=2394&hdl=&np=&adv=yes&ln=&fn=&q=&y1=&y2=&ci=Chicago&co=&mhd=&shd=}}</ref> ==Legacy== Frost's research focused on the determination of [[radial velocity]] using stellar spectroscopy and [[spectroscopic binaries]].<ref name="fox">{{Cite document | first = Philip | last = Fox | author-link = Philip Fox (astronomer) | title = Edwin Brant Frost, 1866-1935|date=January 1936| publisher = [[The Astrophysical Journal]]| bibcode = 1936ApJ....83....1F | postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref> In 1902, he discovered the strange behavior of [[Beta Cephei]], which later became the prototype for [[Beta Cephei variable]] stars.<ref name="struve"/> He played a significant role in bringing [[Otto Struve]] to the [[United States]], when the latter was living as an impoverished refugee in [[Turkey]] after the [[Russian Revolution of 1917|Russian Revolution]]. He later supported the appointment of Struve as his successor as director of Yerkes Observatory.{{Citation needed|date=June 2008}} [[Asteroid]] [[854 Frostia]] is named in his honor. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://astro.uchicago.edu/yerkes/virtualmuseum/Frost.html Biography] {{Dead link|date=June 2008}} {{Authority control|VIAF=121883868}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Frost, Edwin}} [[Category:1866 births]] [[Category:1935 deaths]] [[Category:American astronomers]] [[Category:University of Chicago faculty]] [[Category:People from Brattleboro, Vermont]] {{US-astronomer-stub}}
